segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Bypass traverse checking security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Bypass traverse checking security policy setting.

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Bypass traverse checking security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Bypass traverse checking security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines which users (or a process that acts on behalf of the user’s account) have permission to navigate an object path in the NTFS file system or in the registry without being checked for the Traverse Folder special access permission.
segment.target: This policy setting determines which users (or a process that acts on behalf of the user’s account) have permission to navigate an object path in the NTFS file system or in the registry without being checked for the Traverse Folder special access permission.

segment.source: This user right does not allow the user to list the contents of a folder.
segment.target: This user right does not allow the user to list the contents of a folder.

segment.source: It only allows the user to traverse folders to access permitted files or subfolders.
segment.target: It only allows the user to traverse folders to access permitted files or subfolders.

segment.source: Use access–based enumeration when you want to prevent users from seeing any folder or file to which they do not have access.
segment.target: Use access–based enumeration when you want to prevent users from seeing any folder or file to which they do not have access.

segment.source: Use the default settings of this policy in most cases.
segment.target: Use the default settings of this policy in most cases.

segment.source: If you change the settings, verify your intent through testing.
segment.target: If you change the settings, verify your intent through testing.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: Permissions to files and folders are controlled though the appropriate configuration of file system access control lists (ACLs).The ability to traverse the folder does not provide any Read or Write permissions to the user.
segment.target: Permissions to files and folders are controlled though the appropriate configuration of file system access control lists (ACLs).The ability to traverse the folder does not provide any Read or Write permissions to the user.

segment.source: A restart of the computer is not required for this policy setting to be effective.
segment.target: A restart of the computer is not required for this policy setting to be effective.

segment.source: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.
segment.target: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.

segment.source: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:
segment.target: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:

segment.source: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.
segment.target: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: The default configuration for the Bypass traverse checking setting is to allow all users to bypass traverse checking.
segment.target: The default configuration for the Bypass traverse checking setting is to allow all users to bypass traverse checking.

segment.source: Permissions to files and folders are controlled though the appropriate configuration of file system access control lists (ACLs) because the ability to traverse the folder does not provide any Read or Write permissions to the user.
segment.target: Permissions to files and folders are controlled though the appropriate configuration of file system access control lists (ACLs) because the ability to traverse the folder does not provide any Read or Write permissions to the user.

segment.source: The only scenario in which the default configuration could lead to a mishap would be if the administrator who configures permissions does not understand how this policy setting works.
segment.target: The only scenario in which the default configuration could lead to a mishap would be if the administrator who configures permissions does not understand how this policy setting works.

segment.source: For example, the administrator might expect that users who are unable to access a folder are unable to access the contents of any child folders.
segment.target: For example, the administrator might expect that users who are unable to access a folder are unable to access the contents of any child folders.

segment.source: Such a situation is unlikely, and, therefore, this vulnerability presents little risk.
segment.target: Such a situation is unlikely, and, therefore, this vulnerability presents little risk.

segment.source: Organizations that are extremely concerned about security may want to remove the Everyone group, and perhaps the Users group, from the list of groups that have the Bypass traverse checking user right.
segment.target: Organizations that are extremely concerned about security may want to remove the Everyone group, and perhaps the Users group, from the list of groups that have the Bypass traverse checking user right.

segment.source: Taking explicit control over traversal assignments can be an effective way to limit access to sensitive information.
segment.target: Taking explicit control over traversal assignments can be an effective way to limit access to sensitive information.

segment.source: Access–based enumeration can also be used.
segment.target: Access–based enumeration can also be used.

segment.source: If you use access–based enumeration, users cannot see any folder or file to which they do not have access.
segment.target: If you use access–based enumeration, users cannot see any folder or file to which they do not have access.

segment.source: For more info about this feature, see Access-based Enumeration.
segment.target: For more info about this feature, see Access-based Enumeration.

segment.source: The Windows operating systems and many applications were designed with the expectation that anyone who can legitimately access the computer will have this user right.
segment.target: The Windows operating systems and many applications were designed with the expectation that anyone who can legitimately access the computer will have this user right.

segment.source: Therefore, we recommend that you thoroughly test any changes to assignments of the Bypass traverse checking user right before you make such changes to production systems.
segment.target: Therefore, we recommend that you thoroughly test any changes to assignments of the Bypass traverse checking user right before you make such changes to production systems.

segment.source: In particular, IIS requires this user right to be assigned to the Network Service, Local Service, IISWPG, IUSRComputerName, and IWAMComputerName accounts.
segment.target: In particular, IIS requires this user right to be assigned to the Network Service, Local Service, IISWPG, IUSRComputerName, and IWAMComputerName accounts.

segment.source: (It must also be assigned to the ASPNET account through its membership in the Users group.) We recommend that you leave this policy setting at its default configuration.
segment.target: (It must also be assigned to the ASPNET account through its membership in the Users group.) We recommend that you leave this policy setting at its default configuration.
